title: How to Catch Weasels

parts.name: Setting a Trap for a Weasel

steps.headline: Contact your local wildlife agency representative.
steps.description: There are sometimes laws which regulate when you are allowed to trap weasels, and these laws can vary from state to state. To make sure you are in compliance with these laws and avoid costly fines, get in touch with the agency before you set a trap. To find your local wildlife agency, search for your country's wildlife service, then search their branches to see the location nearest you. If you live in the United States, you can see a list of state offices by visiting https://www.fws.gov/offices/statelinks.html.

steps.headline: Secure any animal pens by closing off holes more than 1 in (2.5 cm) wide.
steps.description: To encourage the weasel to enter your trap, first you should close off any access to small animals you have on your property, such as a chicken coop or rabbit pen. Nail ⁄2 in (1.3 cm) wire mesh or hardware cloth across the hole, or cover the hole with a piece of scrap metal.

steps.headline: Purchase an extra-small live trap if you don’t already have one.
steps.description: Box traps are usually the most efficient way to trap an animal without harming it. Look for one with wire or mesh sides, and don’t use a trap with any sharp edges or which has rusted. You can get a small trap for about $25 from an animal supply or hardware store.

steps.headline: Bait your trap with fresh meat.
steps.description: Since weasels are carnivores, the best way to lure them into the trap is with fresh, raw meat. Set the bait far enough back so that the weasel must go all the way in the trap to retrieve it. Popular baits for attracting weasels include liver, fish, and chicken entrails. Try to buy your meat right before you set the trap so it won’t have time to spoil.

steps.headline: Place your trap where the weasel has been active.
steps.description: Weasels almost never go out into the open, so try to nestle your trap somewhere hidden, close to where you suspect it has been hunting. You may be able to tell where the weasel has been by small, 5-toed tracks, or based on the locations of its prey. You may want to place the trap near a chicken coop or pen, inside of a barn, at the base of a tree, or along a stream or creek.

steps.headline: Set the trap by pushing back the door mechanism.
steps.description: The door should click into place when you have pushed it back all the way. When the weasel goes into the trap to retrieve the bait, he will step on a pressure plate which will release a latch, causing the door of the trap to shut.

steps.headline: Check the trap every 2-3 hours.
steps.description: It’s cruel to leave an animal trapped in a cage without food or water for long periods of time, so you should check your trap frequently while it’s set. Visiting the trap every 2-3 hours is ideal, but you should never go longer than 8 hours without checking it. Always approach the trap in a calm manner to avoid frightening a weasel if you have caught one. If it panics, it may injure itself on the cage.

steps.headline: Wear heavy gloves and use caution when you’re handling the trap.
steps.description: Weasels bite, especially when they’re afraid, so wear thick gloves and long sleeves. Always carry the trap by its handle and hold it away from your body. To calm the weasel while you’re carrying the trap, drape a towel or blanket over the top of the cage so it can’t see what’s happening.

steps.headline: Relocate the weasel at least 10 mi (16 km) away from your home.
steps.description: Weasels have a range of about 30-40 acres, so you’ll need to take it at least 10 mi (16 km) away from its habitat to ensure it doesn't return. If you live in a rural area, you may be able to take the weasel to an area where it won’t interfere with anyone else’s farm. Weasels prefer a habitat with a lot of water, so try releasing it near a stream or creek. This will also help ensure that the weasel will have plenty of natural prey around. Do not release the weasel on private property, as it will just become someone else's problem. If there’s not a location close by where you can relocate the weasel, call animal control or a wildlife rescue and ask them to take the animal away.

steps.headline: Look for signs that the weasel’s prey was bitten on the head or neck.
steps.description: Weasels kill by biting their prey through the skull, upper neck, or jugular vein. This can cause their prey to look as though they have been nearly decapitated. Many people believe that weasels suck out the blood of their prey. Although they may lap the blood as they eat, fresh meat is their primary form of nourishment.

steps.headline: Check how many animals were killed.
steps.description: Weasels will sometimes go into a killing frenzy, thought to be triggered by the smell of blood. They will often kill more than they can eat and store it for later, especially females that have young kits. Weasels have been known to kill entire flocks of chickens at one time, whereas other predators usually kill only what they need for one meal.

steps.headline: Look for signs that chicken eggs have been stolen or eaten.
steps.description: If you have chickens, you may notice that their eggs are being stolen or that they have been sucked dry. Eggs are not the weasel’s first food choice, but they will steal them if there are no other food sources available.

steps.headline: Watch for weasels year-round.
steps.description: Weasels are active throughout the entire year. They do not hibernate, so if you notice prey is being killed during the winter, a weasel may be the culprit. Other predators, including foxes, are also active during the winter, so this should not be the only factor you consider when you are trying to determine what kind of animal you are dealing with.

steps.headline: Check for small footprints with 5 clawed toes.
steps.description: Weasels have 5 toes on both their front and back feet, and claws are usually visible on each toe. However, their tracks resemble other Mustelidae relatives, including the badger, mink, skunk, and otter, so take pictures to compare to other animals if you’re not sure.
